resource.chars:
VII <u>Concluding Remarks</u>

71  It might be asked with some show of reason, what good purpose
can possibly be answered by such a minute and prolix description of a
type of animal structure, so mean and insignificant as that which has
been occupying our attention. To such a question I should reply _ First
that I hold it to be worthy labour to learn, and to place within
reach of others, <u>everything</u> that <u>can</u> be learned respecting <u>any</u> form
of Organized Being; that such a complete acquaintance is the great
desideratum in every department of Biological Science; and that
no works have ever excercised so beneficial an influence on its
progress, as those admirable Monographs of single species,
which, by thoroughly elucidating their structure and
physiological history, have served as a basis for all subsequent
enquiry into the nature of the Plants or Animals formed on a
like plan _ Secondly, such an enquiry can scarcely be otherwise
than of peculiar utility, as relating to a tribe of Animals whose
nature and history are almost as unknown to us now, as <s>the</s> those of Polypes
were to the Naturalists of a century ago, when Trembley wrote his
immortal "Memoires pour servir à l'Histore d'un Genre de
